comments.commentBody: Phoenix to Tucson makes sense as a rail line, but when you get to either end you face a common dilemma...you need a car to get around both towns, each covering hundreds if square miles.  Thus, it's only half a solution in search of a problem.

This article makes me to feel that America and India are both sides of the same coin in the project sequence- planning with big budget, divert the fund ,financial crunch , delay in the execution of the project, election, change of government, delay in project, revisit the project by the new government, finding loop holes in the planning of the previous government, cost escalation, fund allocation based on new estimation story goes on ----- when the project completes ! Thank God!.

How about heroin, crack cocaine?  Addiction causes happiness in satisfying the craving for the chemical.  Nicoitine is highly addictive and tobacco addiction is a treatable disease.  The happiness quotient is a very twisted approach to an industry that creates addiction.

The gunboats have been operating on the Rio Grande since 2012. The signs painted in the sides of the gunboats say “Texas Highway Patrol.” The gunboats are named for Texas state trooper killed in the line of duty and are crewed by state troopers and Texas Parks and Wildlife game warden who are law enforcement officers, not vigilantes. Their primary mission is to intercept and arrest drug smugglers, not illegal immigtrants.  Each year, they arrest hundreds of drug smugglers and confiscate more than one million pounds of heroin, cocaine, meth, and marijuana. Game wardens and state troopers routinely detain illegal immigrants as they cross the Rio Grande and hold them for the Border Patrol;  They are equipped and trained to handle illegal border crossers, but their main challenge is confronting violent drug cartel, including the Zetas, which explains the mounted machine guns and body armor.  The majority of game wardens and state troopers assigned to the border area are Hispanic. Questioning their respect for human lives just demonstrates your ignorance of borderland demographics. The larger Texas border cities are 80- to 90-percent and the small towns are nearly 100-percent Hispanic. Hispanics now outnumber non-Hispanic whites in Texas.

Texas lawmakers and executives complain of a lack of federal funding for unnecessary border security that is rightly handled by the federal government (since it is, after all, a federal border). This vigilantism will likely result in more "accidental" shootings (since game wardens are not equipped or trained to handle immigration issues).

Yet said lawmakers and executives refuse the federal government's offer to fund over one million additional Medicaid patients. Many Texans will die as result.

I wonder how much respect these people have for human lives (or, more precisely, the lives of those who are not of the same national or socioeconomic group).

Smoking pleasure is ephemeral. It is gone in mere minutes. The suffering from emphysema lasts however one's life time is defined. My mother was a smoker for God knows how long, smoking whatever the hills and by ways of Tennessee would produce. She could roll her own with the best of them until she moved west. She also then missed he father's moonshine that she helped top produce for many years along side her three brothers.
She never related lung disease, heart failure,. strokes,or dementia to smoking. Funny she said it was God's will. She was tough. She lingered for 13 years in a skilled nursing
Foe some reason she hads to smoke after we ate snuffing out the cigarette in the baked potato. dropping the butt in the water glass. It was disgusting. Shr would not believe that her lung problems were caused by smoking. the her heart failure was caused by smoking, that maybe her series of strokes were related to smoking. She was tossed from every nursing home we could find because she would bribe the help. At one place smokers were allowed to smoke through their tubes, holes in their throats, however they wanted to get it done. I guess they didn't get that their end was near. I can say that my mother's and father's blowing smoke into my crib probably cured me. Thank God for their foresight.

Psst...if you mean Medicaid reimbursement, it's fully funded for the first three years, and at a 90% rate after that, saving states billions.

And while I object to having your Maximum Jefe siphon off my tax dollars to pay for having people who oughta be checking up on when deer season starts run around with bangsticks looking for toddlers, looks like the rest of us are on the hook for that, too.
i hear Jerry Jeff's working on changing the Texas state motto to "Big Hat, No Cattle."

Texas cross-trains its game wardens to be able to function as any other LEO.
Wise, I call it.
Absolutely. It's not as though Rick Perry's running for Prez and got hammered last go-round for saying decent things about immigration in any way, shape, or form.

I worked at BofA in the mid 70s. Giannini had retired from active management in 1945. Nevertheless, there were vestiges of his management style and it was a friendly internal environment. This was contrasted with a so-called Citibank-style of aggressive internal competition. In those years, BofA reached $46 billion in assets ($232 billion today using CPI) making it the World's largest bank. Indeed, a number of factors starting in the early 80s led to "rationalization" of banks and their practices. Cushy banking lifestyles came to an end. Bank of America is a nameplate only with no relation to the original bank. Besides, the surviving entity was really NationsBank, which was what became of NCNB, a legacy of Hugh McColl's  bank-building empire.

I think B of A hard nose tactics began sometime during the 1980s. Mr. Amadeo Giannini, the founder would be shocked with enormous size and negative actions of the small bank he left. Some of the blame certainly can be traced to Wall Street and congressional deregulations.
Odd, then, that the Gov dragged his feet in deploying the Guard for four weeks or so, while screeching at the President about deploying the Guard, ain't it? Q

The US had nothing to do with the events that transpired in Ukraine. The US did not topple Yanukovych. Nuland was a bit player in all of this but has become a rallying cry for the propagandists.

No one wants trouble with Russia. It's a pointless exercise that benefits no one.

Putin has brought all of this on himself. He is the one that ordered the invasion and annexation of Crimea. He's the one that had his Parliament grant him the right to invade Ukraine, which has, thankfully, been rescinded but could be reinstated in a heartbeat. Putin is the one that sent protesters, the separatist leaders, then mercenaries into eastern Ukraine.

To blame any of what Putin has done on former ambassador McFaul is just ridiculous.

All the monies spent by the US on various projects (anti-AIDS, journalism scholarships etc etc etc) are accounted for on US gov't public websites.

The rest of you comment is just crazy anti-US ranting: guess what, the head of the CIA does not routinely "tell the US public" where he is going, although they usually find out because there is a working press in the US- see: how did you find out about this "secret voyage"?

Roger Binion, Moscow, Russia -- "The US had nothing to do with the events that transpired in Ukraine."

"Nothing?" Really? 5 billion dollars and caught in the act with audio played for all to hear, and you still say it's "nothing?"

I suppose Brennan and Biden rushed there the day before each major event, and Biden's son is suddenly on the Board of the biggest oil firm, all because we had "nothing" to do with there things.

Who do you really work for in Moscow?

This author was the non-diplomat private ideolog sent as Ambassador to Russia because he was a bare-knucles advocate of the neocon school. He kept the Russian offended full time. It was guys like him, with Victoria Nuland, who created this crisis. They sustain this as a crisis. They want trouble with Russia -- that is their goal.

We ought to have learned after Iraq that these guys lead us only into disaster. Their perverse view of the world does not work, and only causes us to do things harmful to ourselves.

We need actual diplomacy, by actual diplomats, not this nonsense.

Actually, smoking was banned in those places a long time ago ...getting some mileage out of that one, eh?  Well, except for "parties" or "dinners".  I guess people such as yourself will have to just deal with what others do in their own homes by, lets say, NOT GOING THERE.

What about the happiness gained by us asthma patients and many other patient groups (heart patients, pregnant mothers etc.( who can visit friends, go to dinners and parties and restaurants, fly on planes etc.) It wasn't so long ago that none of the above was possible.
Hopefully they are working on a plan to keep Mr Perry in!

Smokers had better enjoy the happiness of smoking because they aren't going to continue experiencing the happiness of sex. Beyond the turnoff of smelling like a dirty ashtray, smoking leads to impotence because of the constricting effect of nicotine, particularly on the small blood vessels of the body (same cause of heart attacks, strokes, kidney cancers, etc.) I'm sure e-cigs will end up causing the same thing. Nicotine is nicotine.

The best anti-smoking message, which for some reason disappeared all too quickly from tv, showed a cigarette suddenly turning limply downward as a woman walked by. If that effective public service message had run longer than a mere few months, everyone would know about the 'downside'.

Yep, the average cost of educating a single child in public school is $10,500 per year (2012 figures). These tens of thousands of children brought illegally across our borders are enrolled in our public schools, depriving our own children of scarce resources. It is telling that the same people who whine about the public school system not having enough funding are welcoming tens, possibly hundreds of thousands of extra burdens.

I am sympathetic to the plight of these children, but we cannot be the charity haven for the whole world. Our own people are hurting. Let's take care of our own for a change.

Yes but linh you do understand , don't you, that all that counts when policy decisions are being made is how something affects populations. Sorry to hear about your cousin, and i hope you stay well, but lung cancer affects smokers much more frequently than it affects non smokers, by a massive margin.

I really hope you don't talk the way you write here when in the presence of young people.

By the way, as a smoker you smell vile to a non smoker. The fact that no one likes to tell you doesn't change that.

If that's true, which I expect it's not completely, you're an outlier. The statistics on smoking are consistent and uncontroverted: Most people who smoke regularly suffer serious health consequences. Not recognizing that you're an exception does no favors to the folks you tell this to.

surely you spoke without participatory knowledge: you have not been in my vicinity, in my home, office, or car.
my sense of smell is acute. my pressure and sugar are low, my heart rate that of a 20 year old.
there is no risk - even if they were next to the ashtray.
finally, when people and/or customers are here, the comment when i choose to smoke is: "i didn't know you smoke",
so put it in your hat, dear.

1. my best first cousin has lung cancer and has never smoked.

2. i have smoked for 46 years so far. lung xrays are clear as a much younger non-smoking person's. no shortness of breath, etc. no one who comes into my home or office remarks about smoke or smells.

3. guess i'll have to stop when they nail the box shut.
Thank you, Ken. I'm sure that there will be buckets of tears of joy this coming New Year's Eve.
Do these clowns have any idea how pleasurable it is to successfully quit smoking?
Where does the article say that he has a legally-binding plea agreement?

A perfect cost-benefit analysis would include the pleasures, but it would also include the pains, which I would bet far outweigh those pleasures -- all the disability and pain in your lungs, the loss of vitality and energy, the decreased sexual ability and impotence, the pain of cancer, the many lost years of life, the decreased ability to attract and keep a mate, being a chimney and smelling like an ash tray, the many lost years of life, and on and on. Of course you would also include this in the cost-benefit analysis, and it would probably make for a strongly negative "discount factor".

@CityBumpkin,

The FBI and US Attorney's Office who made the deal were lawyers. They knew how to make a deal.

They never said that he would get him an S visa -- they said that they would *do all they could* to get him an S visa. They did all they could. That was the deal. He didn't get it. They fulfilled their part of the deal.

Sometimes deals go bad. Every drug dealer knows that.
What's intelligence has to do with per-capita income? Are suggesting that out of work people are less smart than people with good jobs? You really should start reexamining your own intellect.

Almost every disease is made more likely, debilitating, and painful, to you and those who have to take care of you -- take for example the horrendous costs of a stroke, a heart attack, all made far more likely and common from smoking, of course, if you're going to include any pleasures from smoking in your cost-benefit analysis, these and all the terrible pains and costs from smoking should be included, which will probably dwarf any pleasures.

And all the pain and suffering you cause to your loved ones, friends, those around you from your decision to smoke and all of the disability, illness, and death it causes. Of course, that should also be included in the cost-benefit analysis.
